content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Emily Johnson: I was born in Madison, Wisconsin, and I've lived here most of my life. My childhood wasn't easy. My parents were divorced when I was young, and we struggled financially. My mom worked a lot of hours at a local grocery store, and my dad wasn't really around after the divorce. We lived in a small apartment, and I remember always being aware of money — never having enough for things other kids took for granted. I was raised Catholic, but I haven't been religious since I was a teenager. I graduated high school, but I didn't go to college because I couldn't afford it, and I didn't have much support to help me figure out what I wanted to do next. I tried a few jobs, but nothing really stuck. I've been laid off a couple of times, and it's been tough trying to find steady work. I'm still figuring out my path, but I hope to get back on my feet soon.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Emily Johnson: There was a moment when I was 17, right after high school, when I had to choose between staying in Madison or moving to another city with a cousin who had a job and was offering me a place to stay. I was really torn because I didn't want to leave my mom alone, but I also knew that if I stayed, I wouldn't have any direction. I remember sitting on the floor of our apartment, staring at the ceiling, thinking about what my life could be if I took that chance. In the end, I decided to stay, thinking I could figure things out later. That decision probably kept me from getting a foot in the door somewhere else, and it's something I think about often. I wonder what my life would be like if I had taken that risk.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Emily Johnson: I think I made the choice consciously, even if it wasn't the easiest one. I remember feeling like I had to be strong for my mom, like leaving would be abandoning her. But deep down, I knew I was staying out of fear — fear of the unknown, fear of failing, fear of not being able to come back. I didn't want to admit that I was scared, so I told myself I was making the right decision. Looking back, I realize that fear held me back more than anything else. I wish I had been brave enough to take that chance, even if it meant being away from her for a while.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Emily Johnson: Yeah, I think if someone had reached out — maybe a counselor at school, or even a relative who could have helped me see things differently — it might have made a difference. But I didn't know where to turn. I felt like I was on my own, and I didn't want to bother anyone else with my problems. I guess I was too proud or too scared to ask for help. It's funny, though — I remember my mom tried to talk to me about it, but I just shut her down. I didn't want her to feel like I was leaving her behind, even though I knew I needed to grow. I wish I had been more open, more honest with her. Maybe then I would have had the support I needed to take that step.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Emily Johnson: I don't have a partner or children right now. My mom is still the most important person in my life, even though we've had our struggles. She's been through a lot, and I feel like I've let her down in some ways. I try to stay in touch, but life has a way of pulling you in different directions. I have a few cousins who I keep in contact with, and they've been pretty supportive. One of them, the one I almost moved with when I was 17, still checks in on me sometimes. I guess I don't have a lot of people in my life, but the ones I do have, I value. I just wish I had been more open with my mom back then — maybe things would have turned out differently for both of us.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of memories and emotions to the surface. It felt like I was walking through my own life again, from the struggles of my childhood to the tough decisions I made as a teenager. I realized how much I've carried on my own, not asking for help even when I needed it most. Talking about my mom and that moment at 17 made me feel both sad and grateful. Sad because I know I missed opportunities, but grateful that I still have her in my life, even if we're not as close as I wish we were. It's been a long journey, and I'm still figuring things out, but I hope that by reflecting on these moments, I can start to move forward with more courage and openness.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Emily Johnson: My dad isn't really a part of my life anymore. After the divorce, he moved out of state and didn't stay in touch much. I remember him being around when I was really little, but after a while, he just faded out. I don't even know where he is now or if he's still in the country. I guess I don't think about him much, except for the occasional memory — like when I was sick as a kid and he stayed up with me, or when he taught me how to ride a bike. But those moments feel like they happened to someone else. I don't hold any resentment toward him, but I also don't feel any connection. My mom and I have our ups and downs, but at least we're still in each other's lives, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Emily Johnson: I have a few friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, though we don't see each other as often as we used to. One of them, Sarah, was like a sister to me — we used to hang out all the time, and she was always the one who encouraged me to dream bigger. She ended up going to college and is now working in social services, which is pretty cool. She's tried to check in on me from time to time, but I guess life got in the way. I feel bad about that, honestly. I know she cares, but I haven't been the best at staying connected. There's also this guy named Jake who I used to work with at the grocery store where my mom worked. We became pretty close for a while, but things kind of fizzled out when I got laid off. I think I was too focused on my own struggles to really invest in a relationship. I don't know — maybe I'm just not great at maintaining relationships. But I do miss having someone to talk to, someone who isn't just family. I guess I'm learning, though. I've started going to a community center sometimes, and there are a few people there who are nice and who I've started talking to. It's not the same as having close friends, but it's a start.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Emily Johnson: I live in a pretty run-down part of Madison — one of those neighborhoods where the houses are old, the streets aren't always in great shape, and there's a lot of people who are just trying to get by. It's not dangerous, not really, but you can tell it's been neglected for a while. There's a small park nearby where I sometimes sit and people-watch, just to clear my head. The community center I mentioned earlier is right across the street from my apartment, so that's been a good place to meet people. My apartment itself is pretty small, just one bedroom and a kitchen, but it's all I can afford right now. I like the quiet, though — it gives me space to think, to reflect on things. I know it's not much, but it's mine, and that means something. I used to dream of living somewhere bigger, somewhere with more opportunities, but I guess I'm learning to make the most of what I have here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Emily Johnson: I feel safe here, mostly. There's a sense of familiarity, like I know the people who walk these streets, even if I don't always know their names. I've never had anything stolen or been threatened, so I guess that's something. But there's also a part of me that feels like I'm stuck — like no matter how safe it is, this neighborhood doesn't offer the kind of future I want. I see kids playing in the park, and I wonder if they have more opportunities than I did. I guess I'm not scared of the place itself, but more of what it represents — the limitations, the lack of resources, the feeling that you're always one step behind. It's not unsafe, but it's not exactly a place where dreams take root either.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Emily Johnson: It's been a mix of things, honestly. On one hand, I appreciate the quiet and the fact that I don't have to worry about being judged or looked down on here. People are pretty much like me — struggling, trying to make ends meet, figuring life out as we go. That sense of shared experience can be comforting, in a way. But on the other hand, it's hard not to feel like I'm stuck in a cycle. I see the same faces, the same problems, the same lack of opportunity. I used to think that if I just worked harder, things would change, but I've started to realize that it's not just about me. It's about the system, the resources, the support — or lack thereof — that's available. I want more for myself, but I also don't want to lose hope. I guess I'm learning to be patient, to take small steps, and to believe that even in a place like this, there's still a way forward.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much I've been holding onto the past — especially when it comes to my mom and the choices I made as a teenager. It's strange how talking about those things now brings up so many feelings, both good and bad. I miss the closeness I used to have with my mom, but I also know that my decisions back then were shaped by fear and a lack of support. I guess I've been trying to make up for that by staying in touch, even if it's not as much as I'd like. And then there's the neighborhood — it's safe, but it feels like a place where dreams don't really take root. I see the same struggles around me, and it makes me wonder if I'm just repeating the same cycle. But I'm also learning that it's okay to take small steps, to find comfort in the people around me, and to believe that even in a place like this, there's still a way forward. I just hope I can be more open, more honest, and more brave — not just for myself, but for the people I care about.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Emily Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty routine, honestly. I usually wake up around 8 or 9 in the morning, depending on how I slept the night before. I don't have a lot of structure, so some days I feel more motivated than others. I work part-time at a local café most days, though the hours aren't steady — sometimes I'm there for a few hours, sometimes not at all. When I'm not working, I try to spend time at the community center, just hanging out with people, listening to music, or reading. I've started taking some online classes through a local program, mostly just to keep my mind active and to see if I can get my foot in the door somewhere. On weekends, I like to go to the park, sit by the lake, and just think. It's peaceful there, and I feel like I can breathe a little easier. But honestly, most of my week is just about getting by — paying bills, trying to save a little, and hoping that something changes soon. I guess I'm just waiting for that moment when things start to shift, even if I don't know exactly how or when it'll happen.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Emily Johnson: I work part-time at a local café, mostly mornings, though the hours can be pretty inconsistent. Some weeks I'm there five days, other weeks just two or three. It's not much pay, and the shifts are short, but it helps cover the basics — rent, groceries, the occasional bus fare. I've also done some odd jobs around the neighborhood, like helping neighbors with yard work or cleaning their homes when they're away. It's not glamorous, but it keeps me busy and gives me a sense of purpose, even if it's small. I've been thinking about getting some training for something else, maybe something in customer service or office work, but I don't know where to start. I guess I'm just taking it one day at a time, hoping that eventually, something better comes along.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Emily Johnson: I also try to keep up with my mom as much as I can, even if it's just calling her on the phone or stopping by for dinner once in a while. She still worries about me, and I know I should be doing more to make her feel like I'm on a better path. I used to feel like I was letting her down, but now I try to remind myself that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. I also have this little routine where I write in a journal every now and then — not often, but when I feel like I need to process something. It's not much, but it helps me sort through my thoughts. And I've started going to a few support groups at the community center, just to see if talking to others who are going through similar things might help me feel less alone. It's a small step, but I think it's one that matters.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Emily Johnson: One of the bigger changes has been starting to get more involved with the community center — not just hanging out there, but actually signing up for some workshops and classes. I took a basic computer skills class a few weeks ago, and it was actually pretty helpful. I never realized how much I didn't know, and now I feel like I can at least apply for some jobs online or look for resources I didn't know existed. I also started volunteering there a couple of times a week, helping out with administrative tasks or just being there for people who need someone to talk to. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of purpose and connection that I haven't felt in a while. I guess I'm starting to realize that change doesn't always come in big, dramatic moments — sometimes it's just little steps, like showing up to a class or saying yes to helping someone else. It's still early, but I'm hoping these small changes add up to something bigger over time.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Emily Johnson: I don't have children of my own yet, but I've spent a lot of time thinking about what it would be like to raise a kid in a place like this. I imagine their days would be similar to mine — waking up late, maybe helping out with chores, going to school, and then coming home to a quiet house. I know I wouldn't want them to feel stuck the way I sometimes do. I think I'd want to give them more opportunities, maybe push them to go to college or learn skills that could take them somewhere else. But honestly, I'm not sure if I'd know how to do that. I've been trying to figure out my own path, and I'm still learning. I guess if I ever have kids, I'll have to be the kind of person who doesn't let fear hold them back — the kind of person who encourages them to dream bigger, even if I don't know exactly how to get there myself.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much I've been holding onto the past — especially when it comes to my mom and the choices I made as a teenager. It's strange how talking about those things now brings up so many feelings, both good and bad. I miss the closeness I used to have with my mom, but I also know that my decisions back then were shaped by fear and a lack of support. I guess I've been trying to make up for that by staying in touch, even if it's not as much as I'd like. And then there's the neighborhood — it's safe, but it feels like a place where dreams don't really take root. I see the same struggles around me, and it makes me wonder if I'm just repeating the same cycle. But I'm also learning that it's okay to take small steps, to find comfort in the people around me, and to believe that even in a place like this, there's still a way forward. I just hope I can be more open, more honest, and more brave — not just for myself, but for the people I care about.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Emily Johnson: My health hasn't been the best, honestly. I've dealt with some anxiety over the years, especially when I was younger and feeling like I was stuck with no way out. There were times when I didn't sleep well, when I felt like I was just going through the motions. I used to push through it, thinking I could handle it on my own, but I know now that I didn't have to. I haven't seen a doctor in a while, not because I don't want to, but because I don't have the money or the time. I've started taking some steps to take care of myself — like going for walks in the park, trying to eat better, and even getting some basic health screenings at the community center when they offered them. I know I need to do more, but it's hard to prioritize when you're just trying to get by. I guess I'm learning that taking care of my health is part of taking care of myself — not just my mind, but my body too. It's a process, and I'm still figuring it out, but I'm trying.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Emily Johnson: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that even small things can make a difference — like going for a walk, even if it's just around the block, or eating something that's actually good for me instead of just whatever's cheapest. It's the little things that help me feel a little more in control. But what makes it hard is the constant stress of not having much — not just money, but also time and resources. When I'm worried about paying rent or figuring out how to get to work, it's hard to focus on eating right or getting enough sleep. I also feel like I'm not really allowed to take time for myself, like I have to be productive all the time. It's like I'm always running on empty, and I don't even realize it until I'm already exhausted. I guess I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a luxury — it's something I need to make room for, even if it's just a few minutes a day.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Emily Johnson: In the past two years, I had a pretty bad flare-up of my anxiety, especially after I got laid off again. It felt like everything I had been working toward just slipped away, and I didn't know how to move forward. I started having trouble sleeping, and I would wake up in the middle of the night feeling like I was stuck in this endless loop of worry. I even had a few panic attacks — one of them was so bad that I had to call my mom, and I didn't want to admit how scared I was. I didn't go to a doctor because I couldn't afford it, and I was too embarrassed to ask for help. But I did start seeing a counselor at the community center, and that helped a little. She taught me some breathing techniques and ways to cope with the stress. I still struggle, but I feel like I'm learning to manage it better. I guess I'm starting to realize that my health — both mental and physical — is something I can't ignore anymore. It's part of the journey, and I'm trying to take it one step at a time.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Emily Johnson: Yeah, my health issues have definitely affected my ability to work and focus. When I was going through that bad anxiety flare-up, it was hard to get out of bed some days, let alone show up for work or even leave the apartment. I remember one time I was supposed to start a new shift at the café, but I just couldn't shake this feeling of panic, and I ended up calling in sick. I felt awful about it, not just because I needed the money, but because I felt like I was failing again — like I wasn't even trying hard enough. It's funny, though, because I think that moment was a turning point for me. I realized I couldn't keep pushing through on my own, and I started looking for ways to take care of myself, even if it was just small steps. I guess I'm still learning, but I'm trying not to let my health hold me back anymore — not just for me, but for the people who care about me, like my mom and the friends I've managed to keep in my life.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Emily Johnson: The past year has been a mix of ups and downs, honestly. There were moments where I felt like I was finally starting to make progress — like when I began going to the community center more regularly, or when I started taking those online classes. It felt like I was taking control of my life in small ways, even if it wasn't dramatic or fast. But then there were other times when I felt like I was just going through the motions again, like I was stuck in this loop of trying to get by without really moving forward. I think the biggest thing that's changed for me is that I'm not as afraid to ask for help anymore. I used to think I had to do everything on my own, but I've started realizing that it's okay to lean on others — whether it's my mom, my friends, or even the people at the community center. I still have days where I feel overwhelmed, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself, to take things one step at a time, and to believe that even if progress is slow, it's still progress. I don't know what the future holds, but I'm trying to be more present in the moment, more open to change, and more hopeful that things can get better — not just for me, but for the people I care about too.

Going through the questions about my recent changes and health made me realize how much I've been holding back — not just from myself, but from the people who care about me. Starting to get involved with the community center, taking classes, and even volunteering have been small but meaningful steps toward change. I used to think that progress had to be dramatic, but now I see that it's the little things that add up over time. At the same time, talking about my health made me confront how much I've ignored my own needs — both mental and physical. I've been so focused on surviving that I didn't realize how much I was hurting inside. But now, I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a weakness; it's a necessity. I still have a long way to go, but for the first time in a while, I feel like I'm moving forward — even if it's just one step at a time.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Emily Johnson: I think I've struggled with anxiety for a long time, especially when I felt like I was stuck with no way out. There were times when I didn't sleep well, when I felt like I was just going through the motions. I used to push through it, thinking I could handle it on my own, but I know now that I didn't have to. I haven't seen a doctor in a while, not because I don't want to, but because I don't have the money or the time. I've started taking some steps to take care of myself — like going for walks in the park, trying to eat better, and even getting some basic health screenings at the community center when they offered them. I know I need to do more, but it's hard to prioritize when you're just trying to get by. I guess I'm learning that taking care of my health is part of taking care of myself — not just my mind, but my body too. It's a process, and I'm still figuring it out, but I'm trying.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Emily Johnson: My mom has been going through her own struggles too, honestly. She's been working double shifts at the grocery store to make ends meet, and I can tell it's taking a toll on her. She doesn't talk about it much, but I see it in the way she looks tired all the time, in the way she worries about me even when I try to reassure her that I'm okay. I feel like I should be the one supporting her, not the other way around. But I know she's been there for me my whole life — even when things were hard, even when I made bad decisions. I just hope she knows that I'm trying, even if I'm not there as much as I wish I could be. I think we both need to learn how to be more open with each other, to stop holding back out of fear or pride. It's not easy, but I think it's something we both need to work on.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Emily Johnson: I used to be pretty religious when I was younger — Catholic, like my mom. I remember going to church every Sunday, learning about faith, and feeling like there was something bigger out there. But as I got older, especially after my parents' divorce and the struggles we had, I started to question a lot of things. It wasn't that I stopped believing in God, more like I stopped needing religion to make sense of the world. I think I got to a point where I realized that faith was more about the people around me — my mom, my friends, the small moments of kindness that kept me going — than about prayers or rituals. These days, I don't really think about religion much. I don't go to church, and I don't follow any specific spiritual practices. But I do believe in something — in the idea that people can change, that even in the hardest times, there's still hope. I guess I've found my own kind of faith in the little things, in the people who show up even when life is tough. That's enough for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Emily Johnson: I don't really use social media much, to be honest. I have a Facebook account, mostly because my mom uses it to stay in touch with family and old friends, and I wanted to be able to see what's going on in her life. But I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or posting anything myself. I feel like it's more of a distraction than anything else, especially when I'm already struggling to focus on my own life. Sometimes I see posts from people I used to know from high school — like Sarah or Jake — and it makes me feel like I'm falling behind or missing out on something. But I don't know, maybe I just don't have the energy to keep up with all that. I guess I'm more of a person who prefers face-to-face connections, even if they're not always easy. I like knowing someone's voice or seeing their face when we talk, not just reading about their day online. It feels more real, more personal. I don't know if that makes sense, but it's just how I feel about it.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Emily Johnson: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really used social media for support — not in the way some people do. I know others post about their struggles and get messages of encouragement, but I've never been the type to share that much online. I guess I'm more private, or maybe I just don't feel comfortable putting my life out there for strangers to see. I do feel like I miss out on some connections, though. Sometimes I see posts from people I used to be close to, and it makes me wonder what they're going through or if they're thinking about me. But I don't know — I think I'd rather talk to someone in person, even if it's just my mom or a friend from the community center. I don't want to rely on a screen for support when I know there are real people who care about me. It's just not my style, I guess.

Going through the questions about my health and recent struggles made me realize how much I've been ignoring my own needs — both mental and physical. I used to think that pushing through on my own was the only way to survive, but now I see that it's not just about surviving, it's about healing. Talking about my anxiety and the panic attacks I had after being laid off was hard, but it also felt like a step forward. I didn't want to admit how scared I was, but I'm starting to understand that asking for help isn't a weakness — it's a sign that I'm willing to grow. I still have a long way to go, but for the first time in a while, I feel like I'm not just trying to get by. I'm trying to take care of myself, to be kinder to myself, and to believe that even if progress is slow, it's still progress. I guess that's the biggest takeaway from these questions — that I'm not alone in this, and that there's still hope, even if it's not always easy to see.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Emily Johnson: I think my stress levels have gone up and down, but lately, I've been trying to manage it better. There were times when I felt like I was just surviving, not really living, and that weighed on me a lot. But I've started using some new coping strategies — like going for walks in the park, even if it's just for a few minutes, or talking to someone at the community center when I feel overwhelmed. I also try to write things down in my journal when I'm feeling stuck, just to get my thoughts out. It's not perfect, and some days I still feel like I'm carrying everything on my own, but I'm learning that it's okay to take a breath, to pause, and to not push through every single moment. I guess I'm still figuring out what works for me, but I'm trying to be more patient with myself — to remember that healing isn't a straight line, and that even small moments of peace matter.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Emily Johnson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent and groceries — those are the things that take up most of my paycheck. Rent is the biggest chunk, and it's always tight, especially when I don't have steady hours at the café. I try to stretch my food budget by buying in bulk or going to the discount store, but sometimes I end up skipping meals or buying the cheapest options just to make it last. I also have to pay for bus fare when I need to get to work or the community center, and that adds up over time. I don't have a lot of other expenses, like bills or credit card debt, but I do worry about the future — like how I'll afford things if I ever need medical care or if something unexpected happens. It's hard to plan when your income is so unpredictable. I guess I'm learning to be more careful with what I have, to track my spending more closely, and to look for ways to save even a little bit each month. It's not much, but it feels like a step in the right direction.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Emily Johnson: Honestly, it's hard to say exactly how much I spent last month because my income is so inconsistent. Some weeks I bring in more, other weeks I barely make enough to cover the basics. But if I had to guess, I'd say around $1,200 — most of that going to rent, groceries, and bus fare. That's not unusual for me, though I do have months where I spend a little less if I can save up or get extra hours at the café. I don't usually track my spending in detail, but I know I'm always trying to stretch every dollar. It's not just about money, though — it's about feeling like I'm not falling behind, like I'm doing the best I can with what I have. I guess that's the thing about living on a tight budget — you learn to be resourceful, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Emily Johnson: We rent our home — a small one-bedroom apartment in a building that's seen better days. The landlord is pretty strict about paying on time, which I appreciate, but the place itself is basic, just what I need to get by. I don't own anything really valuable, just a few clothes, some books, and a small TV that I use mostly for background noise when I'm trying to relax. I've never thought about buying a home, not because I don't want to, but because it feels like such a distant dream. I guess I'm just focused on getting through each day, making sure I can afford the rent and have enough food to eat. It's not much, but it's all I can manage right now.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Emily Johnson: Over the past year, my bills have been pretty consistent, but there are definitely times when things get a little tighter. For example, during the winter, the heating bill goes up, and I have to be extra careful with how much I use. I don't have a thermostat, just a basic heater, so I end up wearing more layers and trying to keep the apartment as warm as possible without turning it up too high. Then there's the grocery bill — it tends to go up around holidays or when I'm trying to make sure I have enough food for the week. I also noticed that when I was laid off for a few weeks, my income dropped, and that made everything feel even more stressful. I had to cut back on things like bus fare and even skipped some meals to make sure I could pay rent. It's not easy, but I've learned to be more mindful of when expenses might go up and try to save a little bit in advance if I can. I guess it's just part of the rhythm of life here — knowing that some months are harder than others, but still trying to keep going.

Going through the interview questions about my family and how I use social media made me realize how much I've been holding back — not just from myself, but from the people who care about me. Talking about my mom's struggles and how we both need to be more open with each other was hard, but it also felt like a step forward. I used to think that pushing through on my own was the only way to survive, but now I see that it's not just about surviving, it's about healing. And when it came to social media, I realized how much I've been avoiding it — not because I don't want to connect, but because I'm afraid of what I might find or how I might feel. I don't want to rely on a screen for support when I know there are real people who care about me. It's just not my style, I guess. But I'm starting to see that even small steps — like being more open with my mom or finding comfort in real connections — can make a difference. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be more present, more honest, and more hopeful that things can get better — not just for me, but for the people I care about too.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Emily Johnson: I don't have a traditional savings account, not because I don't want to save, but because it's hard to set money aside when every dollar feels like it's needed for something immediate. I used to keep a small jar under my bed for emergencies, but I haven't really used it much — mostly because I don't know how to build up anything meaningful when my income is so unpredictable. I guess I save in a different way now, like trying to stretch my food budget or finding free resources at the community center. I also try to keep track of my expenses in a notebook, just to see where I can cut back or plan better. It's not much, but I think it's better than nothing. I know I should be saving more, but I'm still learning how to balance between surviving right now and planning for the future. It's a tough line to walk, but I'm trying.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Emily Johnson: In the last year, I haven't really saved for anything big — like a home or even a rainy day. It's not that I don't want to, but it feels impossible when I'm barely able to cover the basics. I used to think about saving for something, like maybe a car or a better place to live, but I always end up putting it off because I don't know when I'll have the money or how long it'll take. I guess I save in small ways, like not buying things I don't need or using the library instead of buying books. I also try to keep track of my expenses in a notebook, just so I can see where I'm spending and where I might be able to cut back. It's not much, but I think it's better than nothing. I know I should be thinking more about the future, but right now, I'm just trying to stay afloat. Maybe one day I'll be in a better place, but for now, I'm just focused on getting through each day.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Emily Johnson: My occupation has been pretty much the same over the years — part-time work at a local café, doing things like taking orders, making coffee, and cleaning up after shifts. It's not glamorous, but it's steady enough when the hours are good. I also do some odd jobs around the neighborhood, like helping neighbors with yard work or cleaning their homes when they're away. It's not the kind of work that pays well, but it gives me a sense of purpose and keeps me busy. I used to think I needed something more — something that would take me somewhere — but I'm starting to realize that even small, everyday jobs can be meaningful if you approach them with the right mindset. I guess I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life, but for now, I'm just doing what I can to make ends meet and stay grounded.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Emily Johnson: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week at the café, depending on how busy they are and how many shifts they need filled. Some weeks I'll work five days, others just two or three. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover the basics — rent, groceries, and the occasional bus fare. I also do some odd jobs here and there, like helping neighbors with yard work or cleaning their homes when they're away. It's not steady work, but it keeps me busy and gives me a sense of purpose. I used to think I needed something more — something that would take me somewhere — but I'm starting to realize that even small, everyday jobs can be meaningful if you approach them with the right mindset. I guess I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life, but for now, I'm just doing what I can to make ends meet and stay grounded.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Emily Johnson: Yeah, I've had a few different jobs over the years, especially when I was trying to make ends meet. Besides the café, I used to work at the grocery store where my mom worked — mostly in the stockroom, restocking shelves and helping customers when they needed something. That was a few years back, though. Then there was this time when I did some weekend shifts at a local library, helping with events and organizing books. It wasn't much money, but it gave me a sense of structure and purpose. I also did some babysitting for neighbors, especially during the summer months when I had more free time. It wasn't steady work, but it helped cover some expenses. I guess what I'm trying to say is, I've had more than one job — just not in the same way most people do. It's been a mix of part-time, temporary, and even some informal work. I never really had a full-time job, and I think that's part of why I've struggled with feeling like I'm not moving forward. But I'm learning that it's not just about having one job — it's about finding ways to stay busy, to contribute, and to keep going even when things are tough.

Going through the questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and how I make ends meet made me realize how much I've been carrying everything on my own. I used to think that pushing through without help was the only way to survive, but now I see that it's not just about surviving — it's about healing. I've been trying to manage my stress better, like going for walks or talking to people at the community center, and it's helped a little. But I still struggle with the constant worry of not having enough — not enough money, not enough time, not enough support. I know I need to be more open with my mom and the people who care about me, even if it's hard. I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help, to take small steps, and to believe that even if progress is slow, it's still progress. I just hope I can keep moving forward, not just for myself, but for the people who believe in me too.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Emily Johnson: I think my household made around $1,200 last month, give or take a few hundred depending on how many hours I worked at the café. Some weeks I bring in a little more, especially if I pick up extra shifts or do some odd jobs, but other weeks it's just enough to cover the basics. I don't really track it in detail, but I know that's pretty much what I'm working with most of the time. It's not a lot, but it's what I can manage right now — just enough to keep the lights on, buy groceries, and pay for the bus when I need to get to work or the community center. I guess I'm used to living on a tight budget, and I've learned to make it work, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Emily Johnson: I've been working at the café for about a year now, though the hours have been pretty inconsistent. It's not the kind of job that offers a lot of benefits — no health insurance, no paid time off, just a few days off here and there when they need me less. I used to think that having a job meant stability, but I've learned that's not always the case. The only thing I get is a small hourly wage and a few employee discounts, which I appreciate, but they don't really help much when you're trying to make ends meet. I've been at other jobs before, like the grocery store and the library, but none of them offered anything better. I guess that's just how it is for a lot of people in my situation — working hard, but not really getting the support or security that comes with it. Still, I try to make the most of it, even if it's not much.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Emily Johnson: My relationships at work are... okay, I guess. I don't have a lot of close connections, but I get along with most of the people I work with. My manager is pretty straightforward — she doesn't really try to be friendly, but she's fair and knows when to give us a break. I don't think she's ever been particularly kind to me, but she also hasn't been cruel. The coworkers I have are mostly people I've known for a while, or at least I've seen around town. We don't really talk much outside of work, but when we do, it's usually about the job or something going on in the neighborhood. I don't know, maybe I'm just not the type of person who builds strong relationships at work. I think I've always been more focused on surviving than on connecting. But I do appreciate the people who are there, even if it's just in a small way. I guess that's all I can ask for sometimes — just being able to show up and do the job without too much drama.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Emily Johnson: My work schedule is pretty unpredictable, to be honest. Some days I know I'll be there early in the morning, other days I might not have a shift at all. It depends on how busy the café is, how many people are working, and sometimes even how the manager feels that week. I used to wish for more consistency, like having the same hours every week so I could plan better — plan when to go to the community center, when to visit my mom, or even when to take a walk in the park. But I've learned to roll with it, to be flexible even when it's hard. It's not ideal, but I guess it's part of the job. I've gotten used to it, even if I don't always like it.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Emily Johnson: Overall, I feel like I'm just barely keeping my head above water. It's not that I'm unhappy — I'm not exactly thrilled either. I know I could be doing better, but I also know that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. There are days when I feel like I'm making progress, like when I start a new class or get more involved at the community center. But there are other days when I feel like I'm just going through the motions, like I'm stuck in this cycle of trying to survive instead of really living. I don't know if I'll ever be in a better financial position, but I'm trying not to lose hope. I think the biggest thing is that I'm learning to be more patient with myself, to accept that change doesn't happen overnight, and to believe that even small steps — like saving a few dollars here and there or taking a class — can add up over time. I just hope that one day, I'll look back and see that I made it through, even if it didn't feel like much at the time.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work hours made me realize how much I've been living paycheck to paycheck, never really thinking about the future or planning for anything beyond the immediate. It's not that I don't want to save or build a better life — I do — but it feels impossible when every dollar is just barely enough to cover the basics. I've always been good at making do with what I have, but I think I've been avoiding thinking about the bigger picture, like what it would take to get out of this cycle. I guess I'm starting to see that even small steps, like tracking my expenses or finding ways to save a little each month, matter. It's not about huge changes right now — it's about being more aware, more intentional with what I have, and more hopeful that things can shift, even if it's slow. I just hope I can keep moving forward, not just surviving, but actually building something better for myself.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Emily Johnson: Yes, my mom worked for pay for a lot of years while I was growing up — probably more than a decade. She worked at the grocery store, mostly in the stockroom and later in the deli section. She never had a lot of benefits or job security, but she always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. I remember her working long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but she never complained. I think she wanted to give me a better life than she had, even if she didn't always know how to make that happen. Looking back, I realize how much she sacrificed, and I wish I had been more aware of how hard she worked. I guess that's why I feel like I should be doing more for her now — not just because I owe her, but because I want to make sure she knows that I'm trying, even if I'm not there as much as I wish I could be.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Emily Johnson: My mom's job was mostly at the grocery store — she started in the stockroom, restocking shelves and making sure everything was in order. Over time, she moved to the deli section, where she sliced meats, wrapped sandwiches, and helped customers with their orders. She worked long hours, sometimes double shifts, just to make sure we had enough money to get by. I remember her coming home tired, her hands always a little sore from lifting heavy boxes or cutting meat all day. She never complained, though — she just did what she had to do. I think she wanted to give me a better life than she had, even if she didn't always know how to make that happen. Looking back, I realize how much she sacrificed, and I wish I had been more aware of how hard she worked. I guess that's why I feel like I should be doing more for her now — not just because I owe her, but because I want to make sure she knows that I'm trying, even if I'm not there as much as I wish I could be.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Emily Johnson: My mom worked at a local grocery store chain — one of those big stores with the bright lights and long aisles. It was a place where people came for their weekly shopping, and she was just one of the many people who made sure everything ran smoothly. She didn't make a lot of money, and the store didn't offer much in the way of benefits or job security, but she always showed up, no matter how tired she was. I remember her telling me that the best part of her job was seeing the customers — the regulars who would wave at her or stop by to chat. She said it made the long hours a little easier, knowing that she was part of something bigger, even if it was just a grocery store. I think she found a kind of comfort in that — in the routine, in the people, in the small moments of connection. Looking back, I realize how much she gave of herself, not just for me, but for the people around her too. I wish I had understood that when I was younger, but I'm trying to make up for it now — not just by staying in touch, but by showing her that I'm learning to be more present, more grateful, and more aware of how much she's done for me.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Emily Johnson: I hope that in a few years, I'm not just surviving but actually thriving — not because I've suddenly gotten everything I've ever wanted, but because I've taken the small steps that add up to something meaningful. I hope I'm still in Madison, but maybe in a different part of the city, somewhere that feels a little more hopeful, a little more like it's possible to build something here. I hope I've finished those online classes I started, maybe even gotten some kind of certification that could help me find a better job — something that pays a little more and gives me more stability. I hope I'm not still living paycheck to paycheck, but that I've found a way to save a little, to plan for the future instead of just reacting to the present. I hope I've made more connections — not just at the community center, but with people who really care about me, who I can lean on when things get tough. And I hope I've been able to mend some of the distance between me and my mom — not because I think I have to fix everything, but because I want her to know that I'm trying, that I'm learning, and that I care about her just as much as she's always cared about me. I don't know exactly what that future looks like, but I hope it's one where I feel more like I'm in control of my life, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Emily Johnson: What I value the most in my life is connection — not just with my mom, but with the people who show up even when things are hard. I think I've spent so much of my life feeling like I was on my own, like I had to carry everything without asking for help. But now I'm starting to see that it's not about being strong all the time, it's about being real, about letting people in even when it's uncomfortable. I value the small moments — like when my mom calls just to check in, or when someone at the community center shares a laugh with me, or when I take a walk by the lake and feel like I can breathe again. I value the fact that I'm still here, still trying, even when it doesn't always feel like I'm making progress. I guess what I'm saying is, I value the people, the little things, and the hope that even in a place like this, there's still a way forward — not because everything is perfect, but because I'm learning to believe in myself and in the people who care about me.

Going through the questions about my work and relationships at my current job made me realize how much I've been taking things for granted — or maybe I've never really seen them clearly. I've always thought of my job at the café as just a way to make ends meet, something I have to do but don't really enjoy. But when I started thinking about how unpredictable my hours are, how little support I get, and how I don't really have close relationships with my coworkers, I felt a sense of sadness. It's not that I hate my job, but I know it's not the kind of work that gives you a sense of security or purpose. I've been at other jobs before, like the grocery store and the library, but none of them offered anything better. It's just the same cycle — working hard, but not really getting the support or stability that comes with it. I guess I've been so focused on surviving that I never really stopped to think about what I want my work life to look like. I want more than just a job — I want something that feels meaningful, something that gives me a sense of direction. I don't know exactly what that looks like yet, but I know I'm starting to see that it's not just about the money or the hours — it's about feeling like I'm part of something bigger, even if it's just a small part of it.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like peeling back the layers of who I am — not just the person I am now, but the person I've been, the choices I've made, and the paths I've taken or avoided. It's strange how much I've carried on my own, not asking for help even when I needed it most. I've thought about my mom a lot, about the decisions I made as a teenager, and how those moments shaped the person I am today. I've also thought about my neighborhood, my work, my health, and the small steps I've taken to move forward. It's not been easy, and I still feel stuck in some ways, but I'm learning that it's okay to take small steps, to find comfort in the people around me, and to believe that even in a place like this, there's still a way forward. I'm not where I want to be, but I'm trying — not just for myself, but for the people who care about me too.
